variant.question: Refer to the image.  Which of the following Metars reflect the weather conditions expected at Brussels airport (EBBR) at 1200 UTC?

options.text: 19022G46KT 1200 +TSGR BKN003 BKN015 17/14 Q1014 BECMG NSW=
VRB03KT 8000 NSC 19/12 Q1012 BECMG 3000 BR=

variant.question: Concerning the radar reflectivity in relation to a thunderstorm, the following is true:

options.text: reflectivity increases with severity and frequency of turbulence and reflectivity is a function of the number and size of water droplets in a given unit of volume.
reflectivity increases with severity and frequency of turbulence.
reflectivity decreases with severity and frequency of turbulence.
reflectivity is a function of the number and size of water droplets in a given unit of volume.

variant.question: While using the airborne weather radar in order to circumnavigate thunderstorms, the radar scope is clear between heavy echoes. Which of the following interpretations of the scope is correct?

options.text: The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. However, this radar scope provides no assurance of being in VMC while flying in this area.

The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received because the number of cloud droplets is too small to generate a significant echo. Thus, the pilot will have a good visual sight of the thunderstorm clouds.
This is a typical radar scope from which the region of clear air turbulence between thunderstorm clouds can be detected.
The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. An aircraft flying in this area will be in VMC due to the absence of precipitation drops.

variant.question:
While using the airborne weather radar in order to circumnavigate thunderstorms, the radar scope is clear between heavy echoes
 Which of the following interpretations of the scope is correct?

options.text: The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. However, this radar scope provides no assurance of being in VMC while flying in this area.
This is a typical radar scope from which the region of clear air turbulence between thunderstorm clouds can be detected.

The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received because the number of cloud droplets is too small to generate a significant echo. Thus, the pilot will have a good visual sight of the thunderstorm clouds.
The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. An aircraft flying in this area will be in VMC due to the absence of precipitation drops.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 050-145.
What is the dark area (around 60 NM / 330Â°) on this weather radar return showing?

options.text: Shadowing
Hook
Scalloped edges
Finger

variant.question: The image on a modern airborne weather radar (AWR) shows a hook shape. What can be concluded?

options.text: The image is a hint to the presence of a severe storm.
The cloud is approaching with a light wind.
This is the anvil of a CB without an indication of turbulence.
The image indicates the presence of a jet stream.

variant.question: Which interpretation of the following message is correct? LFLD AD WRNG 1 VALID 050430/050900 FROST FCST=

options.text: It is forecast that some parts of the surface, vehicles, and aircraft parked outside will be contaminated by hoar frost between 04:30 and 09:00 on the 5th of that month.

It is forecast for the period between 04:30 and 09:00 on the 5th of that month that a departing or arriving aircraft will pass through a layer of ground fog in which the aircraft will be contaminated by hoar frost.
The aerodrome warning for runway 05 due to frost issued at 04:30 UTC has been cancelled at 09:00 UTC.
It is forecast for the period between 04:30 and 09:00 on the 5th of that month that especially an aircraft in the final approach phase will be covered by hoar frost.

variant.question: What is the meaning of the different coloured areas on a plan position indicator of an airborne weather radar?

options.text: Different ranges of intensities of precipitation
Different horizontal dimensions of clouds
Different ranges of cloud thickness (vertical extent)
Different intensities of turbulence (light, moderate, severe) within clouds

variant.question: What is the meaning of the different coloured areas on a plan position indicator of an airborne weather radar?

options.text: Different ranges of intensities of precipitation
Different intensities of turbulence -light, moderate, severe- within clouds
Different horizontal dimensions of clouds
Different ranges of cloud thickness -vertical extent-

variant.question: What is the meaning of the different coloured areas on a plan position indicator of an airborne weather radar?

options.text: Different ranges of intensities of precipitation.
Different horizontal dimensions of clouds.
Different ranges of cloud thickness (vertical extent).
Different intensities of turbulence (light, moderate, severe) within clouds.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the use of airborne weather radar in the vicinity of thunderstorms is true?

options.text: Accurate assessment of the weather ahead of the aircraft might be hampered due to the attenuation of the radar echoes by heavy rain.
The radar reflectivity echoes are much more determined by the number of reflecting particles than by the particle size.
The antenna tilt shall be adjusted in order to receive the most significant echoes (generally received from an altitude of approximately 30000 ft).
The most significant echoes will be received due to lightning discharges near the freezing level.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning the use of airborne weather radar in the vicinity of thunderstorms is true?

options.text: Accurate assessment of the weather ahead of the aircraft might be hampered due to the attenuation of the radar echoes by heavy rain.
The radar reflectivity echoes are much more determined by the number of reflecting particles than by the particle size.
The most significant echoes will be received due to lightning discharges near the freezing level.
The antenna tilt shall be adjusted in order to receive the most significant echoes (generally received from an altitude of approximately 30 000 ft).

variant.question: The type of information given by airborne weather radar is a map with an indication of..

options.text: precipitation and its intensity.
precipitation/obscuration and prevailing visibility.
obscuration and fog.
precipitation and fog.

variant.question: A possible threat associated with the use of airborne weather radar to detect potentially hazardous conditions is

options.text: that heavy precipitation forms a shield for the area beyond where severe weather may exist.
that there is always an error in the determination of wind speed.
the omission of and /or difficulties in detecting moderate rain.
the impossibility to identify the differences between obscuration and precipitation.

variant.question: A possible threat associated with the use of airborne weather radar to detect potentially hazardous conditions is...

options.text: that heavy precipitation forms a shield for the area beyond where severe weather may exist.
the impossibility to identify the differences between obscuration and precipitation.
that there is always an error in the determination of wind speed.
the omission of and /or difficulties in detecting moderate rain.

variant.question: What is the downside of airborne WX radar?

options.text: Severe weather can hide more severe weather behind it.
It uses a lot of electrical power which in turn increases fuel consumption.
Weather radar is very harmful for humans and animals during cruise flight.
Echoes from the radar cannot be properly picked up in CAT.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning airborne weather radar is correct?

options.text: It shows on a plan position indicator the areas of precipitation of rain, snow and/or hail.
It shows the areas which are dangerous for aircraft icing. The intensity levels for aircraft icing as defined by ICAO are indicated by contour lines.
It can also be used for proximity warning and anti-collision protection.
The indication on the plan position indicator represents the amount (mm/h) of water vapour within clouds.

variant.question: Which of the following statements concerning airborne weather radar is correct?

options.text: It shows on a plan position indicator the areas of precipitation of rain, snow and/or hail.
It can also be used for proximity warning and anti-collision protection.
The indication on the plan position indicator represents the amount -mm/h- of water vapour within clouds.
It shows the areas which are dangerous for aircraft icing. The intensity levels for aircraft icing as defined by ICAO are indicated by contour lines.

variant.question: A possible threat associated with the use of airborne weather radar (AWR) to detect potentially hazardous conditions is:

options.text: The heavy precipitation forms a shield for the area beyond where severe weather may exist.
The omission of and/or difficulties to detect moderate rain.
Thereâs always an error in the determination of precipitation direction.
The impossibility to identify the differences between obscuration and precipitation.

variant.question: By use of Doppler techniques, modern airborne weather radar can detect turbulence in:

options.text: Thunderstorms.
The tropopause.
Stratiform clouds.
Clear air.

variant.question: A large white area is visible on an IR satellites image, along with a translucent area on a visible channel image is likely to be...

options.text: Cirrus
Cumulonimbus
Thin stratus
Fog

variant.question: A modern airborne weather radar produces a hook-shaped return as illustrated in the left portion of the annex. This is an indication of..

options.text: severe turbulence and may indicate the location of an embedded tornado vortex.
an anvil at the top of a thunderstorm but without any significant turbulence.
the core of a jet stream with turbulence on the cold-air side of the core.
a warm or quasi-stationary front with a significant shift in the direction of the wind and light showers.

variant.question: An airborne weather radar installation makes it possible to detect the location of...

options.text: zones of precipitation, particularly liquid-state precipitation, and also their intensity
stratocumulus and its vertical development
all clouds
cumulonimbus, but provided that cloud of this type is accompanied by falls of hail

variant.question:
(Refer to image) 
What does the symbol indicate on a significant weather chart?

options.text: The centre of a tropopause "high", where the tropopause is at FL 400.
The upper limit of significant weather at FL 400.
The centre of a high pressure area at 400 hpa.
The lower limit of the tropopause.

variant.question: The airborne weather radar (AWR) can identify:

options.text: Precipitation, some models can also calculate the intensity and predicted turbulence.
Precipitation, calculate intensity, some terrain, and predict turbulence.
Foggy and misty areas.
And clearly show the boundaries of the terrain ahead.

variant.question: What is meant by the information in the attached image?

options.text: Broken (5-7 oktas) Cumulonimbus cloud, base 800 ft above mean sea level, extending to above chart upper limit, severe icing, severe turbulence
Broken (5-7 oktas) Cumulus cloud, base 8000 ft above ground level, upper limit unknown, moderate icing, moderate turbulence
Broken (5-7 oktas) Cumulonimbus cloud, base 800 ft above ground level, upper limit unknown, moderate icing, moderate turbulence
Broken (5-7 oktas) Cumulonimbus cloud, base 800 ft above mean ground level, extending to information missing, severe icing, severe turbulence

variant.question: The Airborne Weather Radar (AWR) can identify:

options.text: Precipitation, some models can also calculate intensity and predicted turbulence.
All clouds.
Areas which are dangerous for aircraft icing. The intensity levels for aircraft icing as defined by ICAO are indicated by contour lines.
Stratocumulus and its vertical development.

variant.question: Which of the following causes echoes on meteorological radar screens?

options.text: Hail
Any cloud
Fog
Water vapour

variant.question: Which of the following causes echoes on meteorological radar screens?

options.text: Hail.
Any cloud.
Water vapour.
Fog.

variant.question: The arrows on the image of a weather radar display indicate..

options.text: shadow areas behind heavy precipitation cells.
areas without precipitation and turbulence.
iso-echo contour areas with strong returns.
clear air turbulence areas indicated by the Turbulence mode (+T).

variant.question: What does the code R24R/P1500 mean?

options.text: RVR RWY 24 right above 1500 metres.
RVR RWY 24 right below 1500 metres.
RVR RWY 24 right 1500 metres.

Snow clearance in progress on RWY 24 right, useable
runway length 1500 metres.

options.text: RVR RWY 24 right above 1500 metres.
RVR RWY 24 right below 1500 metres.
